entry.title: Beyond REST: Exploring GraphQL API Integration in SAP BTP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

GraphQL is transforming the way modern applications connect to and consume enterprise data, offering efficient and flexible querying  developers and integration designers. In SAP landscapes, this means you can consolidate complex integration flows and reduce payload size.

This article introduces GraphQL basics and demonstrates how to integrate SAP Cloud Integration with GraphQL APIs, delivering practical and step-by-step hands on you can apply to your own integration scenarios.

Recently I had an opportunity to work on an integration project where the customer extensively leveraged GraphQL APIs. That's where I thought sharing my experience will be helpful for developers to help in their GraphQL integration journey.

 

What is GraphQL?

Before we dive into actual integration flow, let us first try to understand some basics of GraphQL.

GraphQL is a query language for APIs that executes queries against a defined and a strongly-typed schema. Unlike traditional REST APIs that expose multiple endpoints for specific data objects, GraphQL APIs provide a single endpoint where clients can request exactly the fields they need, avoiding both over-fetching and under-fetching of data.

It is a schema based approach that gives the consumers of the APIs more control over the data retrieval at the same time making integrations more flexible, particularly in complex enterprise landscapes.

Before jumping on the GraphQL integration, first take a look at a sample GraphQL API (which I have also used in my demo)

Countries API: Explore country details such as languages, capitals, and regions.

  • Endpoint: https://countries.trevorblades.com/

  • Example Query 1: Fetch all countries.
query {
  countries {
    code
    name
    capital
    continent {
      name
    }
    languages {
      name
    }
  }
}
​
  • Example Query 2: Fetch country with code
query {
  country(code:"US") {
    code
    name
    capital
    continent {
      name
    }
    languages {
      name
    }
  }
}

In the above two examples, if you see the API endpoint remains same but the query changes based on the desired response. You can add or remove attributes from the query section.

Try out by yourself and you will understand the basics quickly.

 

The Core Challenges

Unlike OData or SOAP, there isn’t a native GraphQL adapter available in SAP BTP Cloud Integration. This means you can’t directly select a “GraphQL” protocol from the standard adapter list when configuring your integration flows. 

Good News: We can leverage standard HTTP adapter for this type of integration.

You must also set appropriate HTTP headers (such as Content-Type, authentication/tokens etc.). Parsing the flexible GraphQL responses often involves extra effort during mapping or transformation compared to protocol-specific adapters.

Another challenge is that as GraphQL provides flexible schema, there is often no OpenAPI or Swagger specifications available for these APIs. This makes integration highly adaptable but developers have to rely on documentation instead of OpenAPI contract like YAML file. Which means you may not be able to directly use standard message mappings directly.

Good News: We can leverage converters (JSON to XML) and groovy scripting extensively to handle transformations and message processing.

 

Real World Use Case

I tackled a real-world scenario which I will explain briefly. The use case centered around synchronizing stock levels between an e-commerce platform and SAP S/4HANA.

  • Whenever the e-commerce marketplace detects an order change, it sends a notification event to the integration flow.

  • The flow receives this event and extracts the order code from the notification event.

  • Using this order code, the flow triggers a GraphQL API call to fetch up-to-date order details for that order code from the customer e-commerce platform.

  • The retrieved order information is then mapped to the corresponding SAP S/4HANA object, enabling an accurate and timely order data integrity within the ERP system.

This integration ensures both systems remain aligned and allows real-time order data synchronization based on event-based design.

To simulate this integration, I used a similar workflow, but using the countries GraphQL API to explain the integration.

 

Integration Flow Walkthrough

In this section, I will walk you through the integration flow (iFlow) to connect SAP BTP Cloud Integration with a GraphQL API. Below is a screenshot of the iFlow design, highlighting the main components involved in orchestrating the request and handling the response.

Figure-1: Integration Flow

We will break down main steps to understand:

  1. How the flow is structured
  2. How the HTTP adapter is configured
  3. How message processing and data mapping are managed for GraphQL integration
  • Groovy Scripting: Groovy gives control for creating GraphQL request. Here is a sample groovy script which I have used
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;
import groovy.json.JsonBuilder;

def Message processData(Message message) 
{
	def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;
	def jsonInput = new JsonSlurper().parseText(body);

	if(!jsonInput) {
		throw new IllegalArgumentException("Input payload is empty or null");
	}
	
	def countryCode = (jsonInput.countryCode != null) ? jsonInput.countryCode : "IN";

	def graphQLQuery = """query {
  		country(code: "${countryCode}") {
  		  name
  		  native
  		  capital
  		  currency
  		  languages {
  		    name
  		  }
  		}
	}""";
	
	// Convert the GraphQL query into a JSON payload and set it as message body
    def jsonBody = new JsonBuilder([query: graphQLQuery]).toString()
    message.setBody(jsonBody)
	message.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");

	//log message body
	def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
	if(messageLog != null) {
		messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("GraphQL Request Body", jsonBody, "text/plain");
	}

	return message;
}​

  • HTTP Adapter: Use standard HTTP adapter to provide GraphQL API endpoint, authentication, additional headers etc. In this POC, I have skipped the authentication piece as our main focus is GraphQL API integration.

  • JSON to XML Converter: After getting the JSON response, leverage the JSON to XML converter to get the XML payload.

  • Message Mapping: Once you get the sample XML, generate an XSD using XSD generator tools. This XSD can be used as a source XSD in the message mapping component. The target XSD is the one which you can get the the target API schema (Either SOAP Or OData) 

I have provided the integration flows in my GitHub

Take time to download the package, deploy it in your tenant and give it a try.

 

Mutations

In the above integration flow, I have only shown how to get the data using GraphQL APIs. But in real world you might also be required to create or update data. The countries GraphQL API is READ ONLY but I will explain theoretically how we can accomplish it in a groovy which you can use it as reference (provided your API supports it).

Suppose I want to update capital name of any country.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;
import groovy.json.JsonBuilder;

def String getGraphQLQuery() {
    return '''
    mutation UpdateCountryCapital($input: UpdateCountryInput!) {
      updateCountryCapital(input: $input) {
        code
        name
        capital
      }
    }
    '''
}

def Message processData(Message message) 
{
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String
    def inputJson = new JsonSlurper().parseText(body)
    if (!inputJson) {
        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Input payload is empty or null");
    }
    // Compose the input for GraphQL variables
    def inputMap = [
        code: inputJson.code,
        capital: inputJson.capital
    ]

    // Build the GraphQL mutation payload
    def graphQLBody = [
        query: getGraphQLQuery(),
        variables: [input: inputMap]
    ]
    def jsonBody = new JsonBuilder(graphQLBody).toString()
    message.setBody(jsonBody)
    message.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");

    // Optional: log message body
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    if(messageLog != null) {
        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("GraphQL Request Body", jsonBody, "text/plain");
    }

    return message;
}

Note: Above groovy is an example to showcase how to build CREATE/UPDATE request for GraphQL API. 

 

Conclusion

Integrating GraphQL APIs with SAP BTP Cloud Integration opens up flexible, dynamic data exchange between external applications and your SAP landscape even without a native GraphQL adapter.

By leveraging the HTTP adapter, Groovy scripting and powerful message processing tools like JSON-to-XML conversion and custom mappings, you can successfully bridge the gap.

While GraphQL’s adaptable schema presents unique integration challenges, it also enables precise and efficient data retrieval. With a clear understanding of the core concepts, tools and practical steps covered in this walkthrough, you are ready to design robust solutions for similar event-driven scenarios in your own enterprise.

Disclaimer: This is not an official reference application or documentation. The thoughts outlined in this blog are based on my real world experience and learnings.

Feel free to “like“, “Share“, “Add a Comment” and to get more updates about my next blogs follow me!

 

References

  1. Official GraphQL Documentation
  2. SAP Cloud Integration Documentation (Help Portal)

entry.title: Cheaper than you think: the Commercial Model of the Event Add-On for ERP explained
entry.content:
Cheaper than you think, more flexible than you expect: the commercial model of the Event Add-On for ERP explained

In the earlier blogs of this series on the Event Add-On for ERP we had already discussed what the event add-on is about and why you would want it. This blog here is about the commercials and to a certain extent about the deployment. This is because the commercials are strongly linked to the deployment of the add-on(s) and their linkage to the Advanced Event Mesh brokers that they hand their events over to.

Event Add-On at SAP Devtoberfest: well worth watching

Before we go there, I would like to point you to two sessions that we did at Devtoverfest just a few weeks ago. You can watch the recordings and specifically the Hands-On session is well worth it. Enjoy!

  • Warp-Speed for Event Creation: Overview on the Event Add-On for ERP

  • Hands-on Session: Practical Demonstration of the Event Add-On for ERP

Commercial Aspects of the Event Add-On for ERP

With that said, let’s now look at the commercial aspects of the Event Add-On for ERP:

  • The Event Add-On for ERP is now available via CPEA, BTPEA, and PAYG.
  • It works for SAP S/4HANA and ECC to create custom events in a low code / no code way.
  • Very important: this add-on only works in combination with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh.

Why is it only available for use with Advanced Event Mesh? Because its commercials are bound to AEM. What does this mean?

  • The add-on gets activated on an AEM broker
  • You set a checkbox on your AEM broker named Add-On Connector Activation
  • This is what you get charged for – AEM brokers activated for the Event Add-On for ERP
  • The actual add-on is downloaded and installed on your backend
  • It can only be connected to activated AEM event brokers
  • You can connect several add-ons to the same activated AEM broker
  • You get charged only for the activated broker, not the installed add-ons
  • You could for example activate one AEM broker and connect add-ons on you ECC and your SAP S/4HANA system to it. You would get charged only for the activation on your AEM broker

In fact, there is no charge other than activated AEM brokers:

  • It does not matter how many custom events are created.
  • It does not matter how many events occur.
  • It does not matter if you combine different backends.
  • There is no consumption charge or anything like that.

Are there other things to keep in mind?

  • Activated brokers are charged on a monthly basis, meaning for a month
  • In the end, you do get a kind of flat rate
  • This means as well that if you activate a broker just for a day, you get charged for the entire month.

Tiered Pricing

The add-on comes with a tiered pricing. What does this mean? In the end it means that if you activate the add-on for more AEM brokers, the price per broker gets lower for newly activated brokers in a higher tier. Important: the price for the brokers in the lower tier does not change, it is the price for the additional brokers.

Find the latest information and the calculator in the SAP Discovery Center. 

A word on the Event-Add On for ERP in the SAP Discovery Center: since the add-on is linked to AEM, you can find the pricing under AEM. Scroll down to the lower part of the Pricing screen of AEM and you will find the pricing for the add-on. It is measured by Connections which is in the end AEM brokers activated for the Event Add-On for ERP. 

 

Pricing Examples

Find some pricing examples below to give you a practical indication of how things fit together.

One connection is charged - even if multiple backends / add-ons are connected - since the activation on the broker is metered, not the number of connected backends

Two connections are charged – since we meter the activated add-on connectors on the AEM brokers

Three connections are charged – since we meter the activated add-on connectors on the AEM brokers and there are brokers for Dev, Q and Prod

 

Summary

The Event Add-On comes with a tiered pricing. It is metered by the number of connections to AEM brokers. The connections need to be activated on the AEM brokers. If the activated connections reach a certain minimal number, the price per active individual connections is lowered according to the specific tier.

Important: if a connection is activated in a specific month for any period of time, the full charge for that connection for the specific month applies

Find the latest information and the calculator in the SAP Discovery Center. As said, look for it in the pricing for AEM since the add-on is bound to AEM.

Useful Links

The blogs of our Event Add-On series:

The E in Event-Driven Architecture: Introducing SAP’s new Event Add-On for ERP

Unlocking the Power of Events: A Deep Dive into the Event Add-on for ERP

Cheaper than you think: the Commercial Model of the Event Add-On for ERP explained

Additional information on the Event Add-On for ERP:

Discovery Center Mission on Event Add-On for ERP and Advanced Event Mesh

ASAPIO Partner Page on the Event Add-On for ERP

entry.title: Introducing a new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages
entry.content:
A new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages has been recently shipped. This is the first increment of the newly split up packages. I hope you remember, with the last update we decided to split up the now deprecated package into 4 packages to better support the setup of multiple pipelines, see New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration.

At that point of time we replaced the scripts from the script collection with local scripts and deprecated the script collection since this was part of the deprecated package anyway. Using local scripts in the generic flow gives us more flexibility in setting up multiple pipelines. However, for the scripts in the provided templates we received feedback that customers prefer to have a script collection because scenario-specific flows are built as copy of the templates and if the local scripts need to be updated then this would result into high maintenance effort. So, we decided to provide a new script collection at least for the templates. This script collection is shipped with the templates package and the templates that uses scripts have been updated to use the scripts from the script collection. If you have scenario-specific flows that either use the old script collection or the local scripts, you need to replace them with the new script collection. Sorry for the inconvenience, but you have to update your existing scenario-specific flows that use scripts anyway because for the new script collection we had to define a new ID.

Besides this change, the new version comes with a couple of new features based on customer demand. The new features are as follows:

  • We now support a generic IDoc outbound flow to standardize and ease the configuration of IDoc outbound scenarios.
  • We now support a generic XI outbound flow to standardize and ease the configuration of XI outbound scenarios.
  • We have improved the support for sender and receiver parties.
  • We have improved the support for receiver-specific queues and the definition of the queue for receiver-specific outbound processing.
  • In a sender wildcard scenario, we now support inbound conversion per sender.
  • Non-XML payloads are encoded before storing in an exchange property to avoid that the payload gets corrupted when reading from the exchange property again.
  • For some scenarios, you have the option to run scenarios in the pipeline without the need of the Partner Directory.

If you like to leverage the new features, you need to update all 4 packages. If you already use the pipeline, your packages are labeled with update available, also for those packages that you created as copy with suffix.

Generic IDoc outbound flow

For scenarios in which Cloud Integration connects to receiver systems exchanging IDoc messages, you can use the generic outbound integration flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for IDoc from the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound.

You can setup the generic IDoc outbound either using one single generic IDoc outbound integration flow across all your receiving systems or using one generic IDoc outbound integration flow for each receiving system. In any case, the generic IDoc outbound integration flow allows you to setup your IDoc outbound scenarios in a common way including built-in support for guaranteed delivery and error handling.

Because we use a generic flow across multiple scenarios, the IDoc receiver adapter parameters and the IDoc control headers are dynamically set during runtime. Here, the following configuration options are supported:

  • Configuring externalized parameters of the generic IDoc outbound integration flow.
  • Maintaining the parameters in the Partner Directory.
  • Creating message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.
  • Defining the IDoc control header in the message body in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.

For more details about the configuration options, refer to the IDoc Receiver Adapter chapter in the help documentation.

Generic XI outbound flow

For scenarios in which Cloud Integration connects to receiver systems using the XI message protocol, you can use the generic outbound integration flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI from the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound. Here, the generic XI outbound flow supports both asynchronous as well as synchronous communication.

Like for the generic IDoc outbound, you can setup the generic XI outbound either using one single generic XI outbound integration flow across all your receiving systems or using one generic XI outbound integration flow for each receiving system.

The XI receiver adapter parameters and the XI header attributes are dynamically set during runtime. The following configuration options are supported:

  • Configuring externalized parameters of the generic XI outbound integration flow.
  • Maintaining Partner Directory parameters.
  • Maintaining message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.

For more details about the configuration options, refer to the XI Receiver Adapter in the help documentation.

Sender and receiver parties

Scenarios with sender and receiver parties are better supported now. We decided to go for a simplified approach by concatenating the party name if any with the sender or receiver component name. The headers SAP_Sender and SAP_Receiver show the concatenated names in the message monitor. In addition to this, we create new headers SAP_SenderParty and SAP_ReceiverParty which can be used in the subsequent flows, especially this is needed for the XI outbound.

If you have a sender party, in the Partner Directory maintain the alternative partner of the configuration scenario as follows: define the agency as a combination of the sender party and the sender component name separated by a dot.

If you have a receiver party, define the receiver service name within the XSLT that you run to determine the receiver and the receiver interface as combination of the receiver party and the receiver component name separated by a dot.

When running the scenario, in the message processing log, the sender and receiver information is displayed as follows:

  • The Sender and the Receiver in the Properties section show the concatenated party/component names.
  • Custom header properties SenderParty and ReceiverParty are added showing the party names.
  • Custom header properties SenderSystem and ReceiverSystem are added showing the component names, here the actual business system names depending on the landscape stage in case that you use the landscape staging feature.
  • If you use the landscape staging feature, and your actual business system differ from the alias names used within the pipeline, the alias names SenderAlias and ReceiverAlias are added as custom header properties.

Receiver-specific queues

By default, each scenario uses the same set of generic JMS queues. For receivers for which you want to control the outbound delivery, you can define receiver-specific JMS queues. So far, this was done for a particular receiver. Now, you can define a dedicated queue for a particular receiver and for  a particular scenario. For latter, you can define different receiver-specific queues for the same receiver depending on your particular configuration scenario. The scenario-specific setting overrides the global setting.

If you like to use a receiver-specific JMS outbound queue across all your scenarios, create a partner in the Partner Directory with the partner ID equaling the business system name and a string parameter with ID ReceiverSpecificQueue. As value, enter the receiver-specific queue name.

If you like to define a receiver-specific JMS outbound queue for a particular configuration scenario only, define a corresponding string parameter for the partner ID representing your configuration scenario. In this case, the string parameter ID is a combination of the constant identifier ReceiverSpecificQueue and the business system name separated with an underscore "_". As value, enter the scenario/receiver-specific queue name.

For each receiver-specific queue, you need to copy the generic outbound processing flow and configure the JMS queue name accordingly. Don't directly copy, instead copy the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound from the Discover Artifacts area of your tenant. This way, the copied flow is still receiving the regular updates if any. As you can see in the screenshot below, we have improved the JMS queue maintenance to be more flexible in defining receiver-specific queues. Besides the prefix you can now also define a suffix. By default, the suffix is empty. The JMS queue name is then concatenated using the prefix, the constant Q04 and the suffix.

And here we go. If you run the scenario, the receivers Receiver_11 and Receiver_12 use the queue defined in the scenario whereas receiver Receiver_13 uses the one defined in the business system.

Inbound conversion

To determine whether your specific scenario needs an inbound conversion, you create a string parameter holding the ProcessDirect endpoint of your scenario-specific inbound conversion flow. So far, you could only define one inbound conversion per scenario. In a sender wildcard scenario, i.e., a scenario in which the same configuration applies to different sender systems, you may have the requirement to define different inbound conversions depending on the sender system. This is supported now.

If you need inbound conversion and you only have one sender for your configuration scenario, create one scenario-specific inbound conversion flow and configure the string parameter InboundConversionEndpoint in the Partner Directory pointing to the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific integration flow.

In case of sender wildcard scenarios, you have two options. If your inbound conversion is the same for each sender system, you only need to create one single scenario-specific inbound conversion flow and hence only have to maintain one configuration parameter InboundConversionEndpoint. If the inbound conversion differs depending on the sender systems, you need to create scenario-specific inbound conversion flows for each sender system and hence have the option to maintain a configuration parameter for each sender system as combination of the constant term InboundConversionEndpoint and the sender system name separated by underscore "_". The system-specific parameter overrules the scenario-specific parameter.

When running the scenario, you can see that the business system BS_DD2_Q with system alias BS_DD2 uses the sender-specific inbound conversion.

Extension for scenario configuration

If you prefer not to use the Partner Directory, you have the option to configure most of the parameters defining your configuration scenario as custom parameters in your scenario-specific inbound processing flows. The custom parameters are passed to the generic pipeline flows and if present the Partner Directory is not called.

For more details about the alternative scenario configuration, see Run Pipeline for Cloud Integration without the Partner Directory.

entry.title: Run Pipeline for Cloud Integration without the Partner Directory
entry.content:
With the new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages, we have added the possibility to configure your configuration scenario without the need of the Partner Directory. If you prefer not to use the Partner Directory, you have the option to configure most of the parameters defining your configuration scenario as custom headers in your scenario-specific inbound processing flows. The custom headers are passed to the generic pipeline flows and if present the Partner Directory is not called.

As you may know, the Pipeline for Cloud Integration is not yet supported on Edge Integration Cell due to the missing support for the Partner Directory on Edge Integration Cell. We do have the support for the Partner Directory on Edge Integration Cell in our roadmap, see Support for the partner directory, but as long as it is not supported you may try out the Pipeline on Edge Integration Cell already today. And once this is shipped, you can switch to the Partner Directory and then leverage the full feature scope of the Pipeline.

With this extension, not all scenarios and features are supported. For instance, we do not support XI and IDoc inbound scenarios because here we do not have an option to define the custom headers in the inbound. Furthermore, we do not support tenant staging and receiver specific outbound queues because here a call to the Partner Directory would be needed.

Also, for content-based-router and recipient list patterns, we can't read an XSLT from the Partner Directory which is the standard approach to carry out the XPath conditions to determine receivers and interfaces. Instead you need to apply custom receiver and interface determination, i.e., calling a custom integration flow where you determine the receivers and interfaces. For this you have different options like running a message mapping or an XSLT, and lately we have shipped options using groovy scripts, see New templates for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration: enhancing the custom receiver determination.

Besides those templates, we also provide a more generic template Pipeline v2 Template Step04 - Custom Receiver Determination in the templates package that you can copy and then upload any message mapping or XSLT. An option would be using the Partner Directory Accelerator Tool for Pipeline Concept to create the XSLT by maintaining the XPath conditions in the accelerator tool. This way, the switch to the Partner Directory once supported would be easier because you can then simply reuse the XSLT.

As mentioned above, for bypassing the Partner Directory you need to define custom headers in the scenario-specific inbound flow. Besides other headers, headers starting with customX are in the allowed list of the generic flows and hence can be passed to the generic flows.

For compatibility reasons, it's mandatory to create the header partnerID. If the header exists, the generic pipeline won't try to map the sender component name and the sender interface name to a partner ID in the Partner Directory. Otherwise, your message will fail.

Let's configure and deploy two different scenarios on Edge Integration Cell, one Content-Based-Router and one Point-to-Point scenario. We will only use the integrated messaging runtime, so we just have to deploy the two generic flows Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Async and Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing on Edge Integration Cell.

 

Content-Based-Router

To run a Content-Based-Router scenario on Edge Integration Cell, we need to create an integration flow which is called to determine the receivers and interfaces. As proposed above, we created the integration flow as copy of the generic custom receiver determination template and used the XSLT from the Partner Directory, i.e., we downloaded the XSLT from the Partner Directory, and imported it as reference to the integration flow.

Next, we need to configure the configuration scenario in the scenario-specific inbound flow.

In a content modifier step, the following mandatory message headers need to be created:

  • partnerID with value equals the configuration scenario name.
  • customXRDEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom receivers and interfaces integration flow, see above.
 
Because this scenario needs an inbound conversion to convert the incoming message from JSON to XML, we have to create an inbound conversion integration flow, and hence have to create the header customXInboundConversionEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the integration flow performing the inbound conversion.

In addition, we created the following optional headers:

  • maxJMSRetries to define a scenario-specific maximum number of retries overriding the default value which is 5. In our case we changed the value to 1.
  • customXPreEnabled specifying the pipeline steps for which we like to call a custom pre-processing flow, in our case for both generic pipeline steps (02 stands for the integrated messaging runtime, and 06 stands for the generic outbound processing). See New feature for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration: custom preprocessing exit.
  • customXPreEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom pre-processing flow.

Once, all integration flows have been deployed on the Edge Integration Cell runtime, we can run the scenario. As you can see in the screenshot below, the custom receiver determination flow has been called. Furthermore, for both pipeline steps the custom preprocessing flow has been called.

 

Point-to-Point

Now, let's setup an asynchronous Point-to-Point (P2P) scenario where most of the pipeline is actually bypassed. For this, we need to create a scenario-specific inbound flow and a scenario-specific outbound flow. The scenario-specific inbound flow directly calls the generic outbound processing flow so that the message is persisted in the JMS queue to ensure restart and Exactly Once delivery. The generic outbound processing flow then delivers the message to the scenario-specific outbound flow.

In the scenario-specific inbound flow, we create the following mandatory headers:

  • partnerID with value equals the configuration scenario name.
  • SAP_OutboundProcessingEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific outbound flow. This header is passed to the generic outbound processing flow which then sends the message to the corresponding scenario-specific outbound flow.

In addition, we created the following optional headers:

  • SAP_Receiver holding the name of the receiver system. This can be added to show up in the message monitor.
  • maxJMSRetries to define a scenario-specific maximum number of retries overriding the default value.
  • customXPreEnabled specifying the pipeline steps for which we like to call a custom pre-processing flow. For P2P, we only use the generic outbound processing, i.e., pipeline step number 06.
  • customXPreEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom pre-processing flow.

Once, all integration flows have been deployed on Edge Integration Cell, we can run the scenario.

For more details, see Custom Scenario Configuration.

entry.title: Integrating Platform Events using Salesforce PubSub Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
In this post, we will explore how to use the Salesforce PubSub adapter in SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI) to subscribe to Platform Events in Salesforce. This approach enables real-time, event-driven communication between Salesforce and external systems without the need for frequent polling or API calls.

What is the Salesforce PubSub Adapter (Sender)?

The Salesforce Pub/Sub Sender Adapter uses the Pub/Sub API, built on the gRPC protocol. It allows SAP CI to listen to Salesforce event streams in real time. Instead of polling for changes or using REST API calls, this adapter maintains a persistent connection to Salesforce’s event bus, capturing events as they occur.

What are Platform Events?

Platform Events in Salesforce provide an event-driven mechanism to exchange data inside and outside Salesforce in real time. Instead of continuously querying Salesforce for changes, external systems like SAP CI can subscribe to Platform Events and react immediately when specific business conditions occur. This results in faster, cleaner, and more scalable integrations.

The true power of Platform Events lies in their ability to capture only the relevant business signals. Unlike Change Data Capture, which publishes every record change, Platform Events allow you to include only required fields, apply qualification rules, and fire events only when specific business conditions are met. This ensures cleaner, lighter, and more meaningful integrations — especially in event-driven scenarios where SAP CI needs to react only to critical events rather than process noise.

Creating a Platform Event in Salesforce

Let’s create a sample Platform Event for the Account object. This event will send qualified Account data.

  1. Navigate to Setup → Quick Find → Platform Events → New Platform Event.
  2. Fill in the details:
      • Singular Label: AccountPlatformEvent
      • Plural Label: Accounts
      • API Name: AccountPlatformEvent__e
      • Description: Event to send qualified Accounts to External system.
      • Leave default retention (72 hours).
  3. Create required custom fields (example):
      • AccountId__c – Text(18)
      • Name__c – Text(255)
      • Industry__c – Text(50)
      • Rating__c – Text(50)

These fields define the schema of your event messages.

Publishing Platform Events Using Apex

Next, we will publish the Platform Event whenever an Account record is created or updated. Below is a sample Apex trigger that publishes an event message, it can be created from Developer console of the Salesforce.

trigger AccountPlatformEventPublisher on Account (after insert, after update) {
    List<AccountPlatformEvent__e> events = new List<AccountPlatformEvent__e>();
    for (Account acc : Trigger.new) {
        events.add(new AccountPlatformEvent__e(
            AccountId__c        = acc.Id,
            AccountSource__c    = acc.AccountSource,
            AnnualRevenue__c    = acc.AnnualRevenue,
            BillingCity__c      = acc.BillingCity,
            BillingCountry__c   = acc.BillingCountry,
            BillingStreet__c    = acc.BillingStreet,
            CreatedDate__c      = acc.CreatedDate,
            CurrencyIsoCode__c  = acc.CurrencyIsoCode,
            Industry__c         = acc.Industry,
            IsDeleted__c        = String.valueOf(acc.IsDeleted),
            LastModifiedDate__c = acc.LastModifiedDate,
            Name__c             = acc.Name,
            Rating__c           = acc.Rating,
            SAPCustomerNumber__c= acc.SAPCustomerNumber__c
        ));
    }
    if (!events.isEmpty()) {
        Database.SaveResult[] results = EventBus.publish(events);
        System.debug('Published ' + results.size() + ' Account events.');
    }
}

Subscribing to Platform Events Using the PubSub Adapter

Once the Platform Event is created, configure the Salesforce Pub/Sub Sender adapter in SAP CI to subscribe to the event channel. Below are key features and configuration parameters:

  • Subscribe to Salesforce channels to receive events.
  • Supports publishing of events to channels with defined schemas.
  • Retrieve schemas using the 'Get Schema' operation.
  • Support for OAuth 2.0 Username-Password and OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer authentication.
  • Replay options to control event retrieval (Earliest, Latest, Custom).
  • Error handling and re-subscription mechanisms.

 Below is the detailed description of each parameter used in this iflow covering Salesforce PubSub adapter.

We are using sender Salesforce PubSub adapter to consume the platform events, configurations are as below.

SAP CI Iflow:

Sender : Pick a sender from the pallet and select the Salesforce Pub Sub Adapter from the adapter list

Configuration of Salesforce Pub Sub Sender Adapter:

Parameter Description:

Host

Specify the host to which the proxy requests are sent for the gRPC API (towards the gRPC host). The proxy requests to the gRPC host will go through the proxy. Example: api.pubsub.salesforce.com

Port

Specify the port to which the proxy requests are sent for the gRPC API (towards the gRPC port). The proxy requests to the gRPC port will go through the proxy. Example: 7443

Tenant ID

Specify the Salesforce Organization ID, this can be found in Company Information within the "Setup" page on Salesforce

Authentication

Select the authentication type to be used for the connection to Salesforce:

  • OAuth 2.0 Username-Password
  • OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer
ℹ️The following fields are available when OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer is selected.

Token URL

Specify the login endpoint to your Salesforce instance url. Example: https://login.salesforce.com for Salesforce production environment, https://test.salesforce.com for Salesforce Sandbox environment and https://{MyDomain}.my.salesforce.com in case MyDomain is enabled on the org.

Credential Name

Specify the User Credentials storing the username-password details.

Security Token Alias

Specify the Security Token Alias that refers to the secure parameter.

This can be omitted if your SAP CI IP address has been whitelisted in Salesforce

OAuth Credential Name

Specify the User Credentials that stores the Consumer key-Client secret pair.

ℹ️The following fields are available when OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer is selected.

Audience

Specify the login endpoint to your Salesforce instance URL. Example: https://login.salesforce.com for Salesforce production environment, https://test.salesforce.com for Salesforce Sandbox environment, and https://site.force.com/customers if implementing for an Experience Cloud site

Subject Alias

Specify the Secure Parmeter that stores the username of the Salesforce user.

Issuer Alias

Specify the Secure Parameter which indicates the OAuth client_id of the connected app in Salesforce for which the certificate was registered.

Keystore Alias

Specify the alias name of the added JKS file in Keystore as a Key Pair. It consists of a key and certificate to sign the JWT

Expiration (in ms)

Specifies the validity of the assertion in milliseconds

 Processing Tab:

 

Channel NameSpecify the Salesforce channel name to perform the subscription. (here we will use the /event/ and then the API name of the Platform event created in previous steps in Salesfoce.)
Replay ID Approach

Select the replay option in the first FetchRequest:

  • Events from a specific position (Custom) 
  • Events from earliest position (Earliest) •
  • Events from latest position (Latest) The default value is Events from latest position (Latest) which allows subscription only to new event messages and does not retrieve earlier event messages stored in the event bus

Replay ID

Specify the Replay ID value. The Replay ID is populated by Salesforce and refers to the position of the event in the event stream. Example: 8381402

Request Batch Size

Specify the number of events to be requested in the Salesforce fetchRequest. The default value is 100

Replay Preset for Invalid Replay ID

Select the replay option in case “sfdc.platform.eventbus.grpc.subscription.fetch.replayid.corrupted” error occurs:

  • Events from latest position (Latest)
  • Events from earliest position (Earliest) The default value is Events from earliest position (Earliest) indicating the earlier event messages stored in the event bus.

Duplicate Check Expiration (in ms)

Specify the expiry time in milliseconds while handling the Duplicate check. The default value is 300000

Process Errors as an Event

Enable this property to write error events in the exchange. If disabled, issues connecting to event streams will only be written to the logs

Deployment of the IFlow:

Now lets deploy the IFlow and see how this works, For demostration, I will create the Account record and then update it.

Demo:

New account created in Salesforce:

As soon the record is saved in the Salesforce, the event/message is generated which is received by SAP CI

{
  "payload": {
    "AccountId__c": "001J100000X6REOIA3",
    "AnnualRevenue__c": 10000,
    "CurrencyIsoCode__c": "USD",
    "Name__c": "Test Account For Demo",
    "BillingCountry__c": "India",
    "Industry__c": "Finance",
    "AccountSource__c": null,
    "CreatedDate__c": 1760449971000,
    "CreatedById": "0055g00000AqVaAAAV",
    "SAPCustomerNumber__c": "101",
    "CreatedDate": 1760449971276,
    "BillingStreet__c": "ABC Road",
    "LastModifiedDate__c": 1760449971000,
    "Rating__c": "Warm",
    "IsDeleted__c": "false",
    "BillingCity__c": "Pune"
  },
  "schemaId": "3lrXZmbw8vDsOdsDj74Qpw",
  "id": "644d0292-d8b7-4fd4-9c5d-5f64eefb7bca"
}

Now lets update the Account and see the event, I will update the name and the City

New event received in SAP CI

In order to see the replay Id of the event we need to check the headers after the Salesforce PubSub adapter step:

Replay Id when Account was created:

Replay Id of the update event:

Observations

  • Only the fields defined in the Platform Event schema are included in the payload. 
  • Each update triggers the transmission of the complete message again.

Conclusion

Using Salesforce Platform Events with the SAP CI PubSub adapter enables truly event-driven integrations between Salesforce and external systems. By defining only the necessary fields and publishing them through an Apex trigger, you ensure that downstream systems receive lean, relevant data instead of full records. The Pub/Sub adapter maintains a persistent gRPC connection for real-time delivery, minimizing API usage and latency. This approach provides a scalable, reliable, and modern integration pattern for enterprise-grade Salesforce-to-SAP scenarios.

Thanks,

Manish Deshpande

entry.title: Automated Job Screening Using SAP Integration Suite, Adzuna, and ChatGPT
entry.content:
Idea

This exercise began as a practical way to explore SAP Integration Suite. Most job portals already provide alerts for new roles, but these alerts are usually driven by simple keyword matching. As a result, many of the recommended roles do not match the actual technical profile of the person receiving them.

The goal was to design an automated process that runs every few hours, retrieves SAP related roles from a job API, and then filters them using a model that understands a specific candidate profile. Instead of relying on keywords in the job title, the screening logic is based on how well each role aligns with a predefined set of technical strengths and preferences.

SAP Integration Suite acts as the orchestration layer. It calls the Adzuna job search API, identifies new job postings that were not seen in earlier runs, and sends each new role to a ChatGPT based classifier. That classifier has been configured using examples of roles that are a good fit and roles that are not, so its APPLY MAYBE and DO_NOT_APPLY decisions reflect the intended technical profile rather than generic matching. The integration flow then aggregates these outcomes into a single HTML formatted email with colour coding, making it easy to focus only on the roles that match that profile.


Overview

This prototype uses SAP Integration Suite to run a recurring process that retrieves SAP job postings, filters out previously seen entries, evaluates new roles with a classification model, and sends a summarized email after each run. The integration flow acts as the central engine that coordinates the API calls, manages state, and assembles the final output.

The flow begins with a scheduled trigger inside SAP Integration Suite. A set of request parameters is prepared for the Adzuna API including job keywords location and pagination details. The integration flow calls the API and receives a JSON response containing job postings for the current page.

The response is parsed to extract job attributes and job ids. A data store holds the list of job ids processed in earlier runs, and this list is used to filter out the roles already seen. Only new job entries continue through the rest of the flow.

For each new job the integration flow creates a structured input message and sends it to a ChatGPT model. The model reviews the job context and returns a category that reflects how well the role matches the defined criteria. The integration flow captures this classification and converts the job details into an HTML formatted block with colour coding.

As the run progresses, the integration flow builds a consolidated email body by appending one formatted block for each classified job. When all pages for the run have been processed or no more jobs are available, the integration flow updates the data store with the full set of seen job ids and sends the final email. If no new roles were identified during the run, the email contains a short message indicating that there were no new results.

Demo

 

Design Flow

The design flow reflects how the integration flow executes each step during a run and how the components work together.

  • A timer event triggers the integration flow at a defined schedule.
  • The integration flow prepares Adzuna request parameters including keywords location and the current page number.
  • The integration flow calls the Adzuna API and receives a JSON response.
  • A Groovy script parses the response and extracts the job details.
  • A data store entry is read to determine which job ids were processed earlier.
  • The integration flow filters the jobs and keeps only the ids that were not seen before.
  • For each new job the integration flow builds a structured classification request and sends it to the ChatGPT model.
  • The classification result is captured and formatted into an HTML block with colour coding.
  • The integration flow appends each formatted block to a single email body.
  • After all pages are processed the integration flow updates the data store with the latest job ids.
  • The integration flow sends a consolidated summary email that contains either the classified jobs or a message indicating no new results.

This design provides a repeatable cycle of fetch, filter, classify, and notify. It combines API connectivity, persistence, and model based evaluation without manual intervention.

Technical implementation

 

 

Main flow

  1. Start Timer
    A timer event triggers the flow according to the schedule. The event carries no payload. All runtime values are set in the next step.

  2. Init
    A content modifier provides the initial control values for the run. This includes
    • Adzuna request parameters such as what, what_or, where, results_per_page
    • The initial page number stored in header pagenumber
    • Technical properties such as emailBody, emailIndex, and the state entry id seen_entry_id
    These values guide the entire flow and are passed into the PageLoop.

  3. Get 1
    Reads the adzuna_state data store using the key seen_entry_id.
    If a state record exists, it contains a JSON list of previously processed job ids.
    If no record exists, the body is empty and NormalizeSeen handles that case.

  4. NormalizeSeen
    A Groovy script reads the data store body and converts it into a consistent JSON array.
    The script sets the output as a property called seen_json.
    This ensures all later steps read the stored state in the same structure regardless of whether it is the first run or a continued run.

  5. Looping Process Call 2
    Invokes the PageLoop subprocess repeatedly.
    The loop continues as long as the PageLoop sets the property hasMore to true.
    Each execution of PageLoop handles exactly one page of Adzuna results.

  6. SetMailBody
    After PageLoop finishes, the final emailBody property is moved into the message body.
    At this point emailBody contains either the full list of formatted jobs for this run or a single line stating that there were no new jobs.

  7. Mail
    Sends the email using HTML content type. The message body created in SetMailBody is delivered to the configured recipient.

PageLoop

  1. Start 1
    Receives runtime properties from the main flow such as pagenumber, results_per_page, and seen_json.
    These control how the page is fetched and how new job ids are detected.

  2. Request Reply 2
    Calls the Adzuna endpoint for the current page using
    • pagenumber
    • what and what_or keywords
    • results_per_page
    • Adzuna credentials
    The response is a JSON payload containing a list of job entries for this page.

  3. DecideAndNext
    A Groovy script that performs page processing. It
    • Parses the Adzuna JSON
    • Extracts job fields such as id, title, company, location, redirect URL, and description
    • Compares each id with the seen_json list from earlier
    • Creates a per page job queue containing only the new job entries
    • Updates seen_json to include all ids from this page
    • Determines if more pages exist based on results_per_page and the number of entries returned
    • Sets hasMore to control whether PageLoop should execute again

  4. JobLoop
    A local process that iterates over job_queue_json created by DecideAndNext.
    Each job in the queue is classified by the model.
    When job_queue_index reaches job_queue_size, JobLoop ends.

  5. PAGE STORAGE
    Writes the CSV representation of this page into the adzuna_jobs data store.
    The entry id is based on run_id and the current page number.
    This allows keeping a historical snapshot of the raw Adzuna response.

  6. SeenToBody
    A Groovy script that moves the updated seen_json into the message body.
    This prepares the body for the next data store write.

  7. STATE STORAGE
    Writes the updated seen_json list back into the adzuna_state data store under seen_entry_id.
    This allows the next scheduled run to continue with the correct state of previously processed job ids.

  8. End 1
    PageLoop finishes and returns control to the Looping Process in the main flow.
    If hasMore is true, PageLoop is invoked again for the next page.
    If hasMore is false, the loop exits.

JobLoop

  1. Start 2
    Begins with the properties populated in DecideAndNext.
    job_queue_json contains all new jobs that were found on this page.
    job_queue_index starts at zero.

  2. NextJobFromQueue
    A Groovy script that reads job_queue_json, extracts the next job based on job_queue_index, and exposes the job fields as
    one_job_id
    one_job_title
    one_job_company
    one_job_location
    one_job_description
    one_job_url
    If job_queue_index equals job_queue_size, the script signals the loop to exit.

  3. BuildChatGPTRequest
    A content modifier builds a full JSON request body using the job fields and the classification prompt.
    The structure includes system and user messages and instructs the model to return APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, or MAYBE.

  4. HTTP to ChatGPT
    The HTTP receiver sends the request to the OpenAI endpoint with the Authorization header set to the configured API key.
    The response contains the generated classification in the field choices[0].message.content.

  5. ExtractChatGPTResponse
    A Groovy script parses the model response, trims the content, and standardises it into one of the three valid categories.
    The output is written into the property classification.

  6. AppendToEmailBody
    A Groovy script formats the job and classification into an HTML block.
    The classification is colour coded based on the returned category.
    The block is appended to emailBody and emailIndex is incremented.

  7. BuildClassifiedRecord
    A script or content modifier builds a compact representation of the classified job.
    Common fields include id, title, company, location, classification, and redirect URL.

  8. write_adzuna_classified
    Writes the classified job into the adzuna_classified data store using id as the key.
    Overwrite is enabled so that if the same id appears again, the new classification replaces the old one.

  9. End 2
    Returns control to the JobLoop wrapper.
    If job_queue_index is less than job_queue_size, JobLoop runs again for the next job.
    If all jobs are processed, JobLoop ends and PageLoop continues with state updates.

entry.title: How to secure your integration flows in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
SAP Integration Suite is basically SAP's way of letting you connect everything, from your old-school SAP systems to your cloud apps. Think of it as the super glue holding all your tech together.

It has tools like:

  • Cloud Integration (CPI) – for creating and handling iFlows
  • API Management – for handling, and guarding your APIs
  • Open Connectors – for third party integrations (like Salesforce, Google, etc.)
  • Integration Advisor – for making B2B connections easier

If you're using iFlows to send important business info, security has to be a priority from the get-go.

Why Protecting iFlows Matters

Your iFlows might be sending:

  • Customer info
  • Financial records
  • Employee details
  • Proprietary business logic

If those flows aren't secure, you could face:

  • Data leaks
  • Compliance violations (like GDPR, HIPAA)
  • System crashes or attacks

Unsecured integrations put your business at serious risk.

Key Areas to Focus On

1. Who Gets Access

Start by making sure only the right people can get to your iFlows.

I suggest:

  • Using OAuth 2.0 for secure API access with tokens
  • Using client certificates for connections between systems or B2B stuff

Don't:

  • Use basic authentication, especially with hardcoded passwords. If you still are, try to switch ASAP.

Also, give people the right roles. Use role-based access control in SAP BTP Cockpit and only give people the access they need.

2. Keep Things Encrypted

Use HTTPS with TLS 1.2 or higher for all data transfers.

For on-premise systems, use SAP Cloud Connector with a list of approved IP addresses and TLS.

For sensitive payloads, consider message-level encryption or PGP steps within your iFlow.

Avoid saving sensitive data unless you really have to. SAP encrypts data at rest by default, but you should still control what data you keep.

3. Design with Security in Mind

Security should be a normal part of your design, not something you add at the end.

Some good ideas:

  • Check all incoming data (use JSON/XML validator steps)
  • Clean up inputs used in Groovy or JavaScript
  • Avoid dynamically evaluating user inputs in scripts
  • Use content filters to block or route unwanted messages
  • Use the Groovy script sandbox to stop access to risky Java classes

4. Secure Your APIs

If you're exposing iFlows as APIs through SAP API Management, make sure to:

  • Use OAuth 2.0 or API key validation
  • Apply rate limiting and quotas
  • Enable IP filtering
  • Check incoming JWTs to maintain identity context
  • Use threat protection to stop XML/JSON injection attacks

5. Monitor and Track Everything

Enable logging and monitoring to spot problems early.

  • Use SAP Audit Log Service to track changes and access events.
  • Set up alerts for suspicious activity, like huge payloads or frequent errors.
  • Use SAP Cloud ALM or integrate with tools like Splunk or Dynatrace to see what's going on.

Logs and monitoring are key for fixing problems and proving you're following the rules.

 

A Real World Example

A factory accidentally exposed an iFlow with basic authentication info that was hardcoded. An attacker found it and got into confidential shipping data.

The problem went on for days because no one was watching or getting alerts.

The result was a data leak, fines, and a damaged reputation.

This shows why even small mistakes can lead to big trouble.

Secure DevOps

Security doesn't stop when you deploy.

  • Use SAP Transport Management Service (TMS) to move iFlows across environments with approvals
  • Keep secrets in the SAP BTP Keystore or Secure Parameter Store
  • Don't put passwords in scripts or config files
  • Automate testing, including tests for bad situations and security regression tests

Identity Propogation

In hybrid integrations, maintaining user identity across systems is important for audit trails and authorization.

Some options:

  • JWT tokens for cloud-based situations
  • SAML assertions for on-premise SAP systems
  • OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion in SAP API Management for secure token exchange

Threat Modeling

Use the STRIDE model to identify risks in your integration design early:

1. Spoofing: Use OAuth 2.0, client certificates

2. Tampering: Use digital signatures, message hashing

3. Repudiation: Enable and retain audit logs

4. Information Disclosure: Use TLS, apply data masking

5. Denial of Service: Apply rate limiting, IP restrictions

6. Elevation of Privilege: Use role-based access control

Metrics to monitor

Track these things to see how secure you are:

  • Failed login attempts
  • Outdated or insecure connections
  • Hardcoded passwords in iFlows
  • How long it takes to fix problems
  • Time to react to security alerts

Use dashboards or connect to your SIEM tools to stay informed.

Security Checklist

Before you deploy an iFlow, make sure that:

1. HTTPS and TLS 1.2+ are enforced

2. Authentication is done with OAuth or certificates

3. No credentials are stored in scripts

4. Sensitive data is encrypted or hidden

5. Role-based access controls are set up

6. Monitoring and alerts are configured

7. API throttling and quotas are in place

8. Input validation and error handling are implemented

Helpful SAP guides:

SAP Integration Suite Security Guide: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite#operate_task-security

Identity and Access Management: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/identity-and-access-management?version=CLOUD

Final Thoughts

Security is more than just a setting. It's a way of thinking.

Whether you're building, designing, or taking care of iFlows, make security a daily habit. Check your integrations often. Look at your logs. Fix problems fast.

Because in today's connected world, your integrations are more than just tech. They're the foundation of your business. Keep them secure.

entry.title: Future-Proofing Enterprise Agility with SAP Integration Suite and Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
In today’s fast-paced digital landscape, enterprises face the dual challenge of accelerating innovation while maintaining operational stability. SAP’s Clean Core philosophy, powered by the SAP Integration Suite, offers a strategic pathway to achieve this balance—enabling organizations to modernize their IT landscapes, reduce technical debt, and unlock agility across the value chain.

What Is a Clean Core?

A Clean Core is more than a technical concept—it's a mindset and governance model that promotes:

  • Minimal customization of the ERP core
  • Standardized, upgrade-safe extensions
  • Seamless integration with external systems
  • Faster adoption of SAP innovations

Individual Dimensions

By decoupling customizations and integrations from the core, businesses can stay current with SAP updates, reduce upgrade complexity, and lower total cost of ownership (TCO).

Why Clean Core Matters

  • Innovation Access: Stay on the latest SAP version and adopt new features faster.
  • Upgrade Simplicity: Reduce manual effort and streamline upgrade cycles.
  • Cost Efficiency: Lower maintenance and operational costs by minimizing custom development.
  • Standard Systems: Make the system or landscape of systems that is as close to standard as possible, while running cloud-compliant extensions and integrations
  • Adaptability: allows to adapt system and system landscape to changing business requirements and in order to adopt new capabilities

Clean Integration: The Backbone of Clean Core

Clean integration is the architectural foundation that supports a clean core. It emphasizes:

  • Standard APIs (OData, REST, SOAP)
  • Event-driven architectures
  • Centralized monitoring and governance
  • Reusable, SAP-delivered content

With SAP Integration Suite, organizations can achieve clean integration through a robust, scalable, and secure platform that connects SAP and non-SAP systems across hybrid and heterogeneous landscapes.

SAP Integration Suite: Enabling the Clean Core Vision

SAP Integration Suite is SAP’s strategic Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS), offering:

🔹Comprehensive Capabilities

  • Cloud, on-premise, and hybrid integration
  • API Management and Event Mesh
  • B2B and B2G integrations
  • Low-code development and AI-powered automation

  • 7,000+ business accelerators
  • 4,600+ APIs
  • 1,400+ business events
  • 250+ connectors for SAP and third-party apps

🔹AI-Powered Innovation

  • GenAI for integration flow generation
  • Semantic documentation (Future Planned)
  • Predictive monitoring and anomaly detection
  • AI agents for test automation and optimization (Future Planned)

🔹Governance & Strategy

  • Integration Solution Advisory Methodology (ISAM)
  • Integration Assessment tools
  • Interface repository for transparency
  • Center of Excellence for long-term governance

 

Achieving Clean Core with SAP Integration Suite

Migration & Modernization: A Strategic Imperative

With the sunset of legacy platforms like SAP PI/PO and Neo, transitioning to SAP Integration Suite is not just recommended—it’s urgent. SAP offers:

  • Migration assessment tools
  • Semi-automated migration flows
  • Edge Integration Cell for on-premise scenarios
  • Partner solutions for regression testing

How to achieve clean integrations

  • Unlock agility and innovation with a future-ready integration strategy
    • Define your strategy using the SAP Integration Solution Advisory Methodology.
    • Design a future-state architecture based on cloud-native principles, API-first connectivity, and event-driven models.
    • Establish strong governance to enforce standards and stay aligned.
    • Define a transformation road map toward your target architecture
  • Accelerate productivity and efficiency with best practices and modern technologies
    • Implement an event-driven architecture for real-time responsiveness.
    • Leverage SAP best practices and accelerators (e.g., SAP Business Accelerator Hub).

  • Empower excellence and adaptability through operational excellence
    • Create implementation design guidelines to enforce consistency and high standards.
    • Apply comprehensive documentation strategies for full transparency.

  • Enable continuous innovation through regular optimization
    • Ensure visibility with an interface repository across your integration landscape.
    • Conduct thorough migration evaluations for informed decisions.
    • Regularly review and refine your integration architecture for ongoing optimization.

 

Integration Maturity Levels

Guiding Principles for Clean Core & Integration

  1. Decouple Extensions: Use side-by-side extensibility via SAP BTP.
  2. Standardize Integrations: Leverage SAP-delivered APIs and events.
  3. Modernize Continuously: Avoid lift-and-shift; embrace transformation.
  4. Govern Strategically: Establish CoE and enforce clean core principles.

Start Your Journey Today

The journey to a Clean Core is iterative, but with the right strategy, governance, and tools like SAP Integration Suite, organizations can unlock agility, reduce costs, and future-proof their enterprise. Whether you're starting fresh or modernizing legacy integrations, SAP offers the roadmap, content, and support to guide your transformation.

entry.title: A Practical Guide to Transitioning from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
TL;DR (AI-assisted)

  • SAP has invested heavily to help customers move from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite across each of the common customer transition paths.
  • Product and tooling improvements ease transition: Improved features, and enhanced migration assessment (modernization recommendations, scenario clustering, message metrics) and migration tooling (pipeline support, automated discovery, receiver-determination migration).
  • Enablement and programs: Migration Guide, upskilling course in SAP Learning, Discovery Center mission, partner ecosystem and certified migration partners, SAP Migration Factory (free assessment and personalized plan), plus Transformation Incentives.
  • Testing and validation: up to 12 months free access to automated testing tools (Figaf Migration Edition and INT4 Shield) when migrating from SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite.
  • Ongoing support and transparency: quarterly “What’s New” blogs, roadmap visibility, community resources and partner-authored migration guides to support phased or hybrid approaches.

---------------------------------------

Since my last post Elevate from SAP Process Orchestration and Modernize your integration platform with SAP Integration Suite, we’ve continued to invest heavily in the program and product-level that help customers move reliably and quickly.

Over the last several months we’ve seen customers pick different transition paths depending on business drivers, risk tolerance, and resource availability. The paths we most commonly observe are — Modernization, Consolidation, and Lift-and-Shift — each have clear advantages and trade-offs. In this blog, I will be describing these approaches and outline how we help making each of these transition paths much easier.

Transition Path 1: Modernization

Customers start on this path to ensure that integrations are also cloud-native and leverage the benefit of API/event-driven architecture using SAP Integration Suite and supporting cloud services.

This approach is preferred by customers who prioritize innovation, scalability, and long-term agility. While it does involve longer timeline to realize full benefits and may require investment into upgrading skills to understand the new paradigms, the customers will find long-term TCO benefits as this path helps in improving developer productivity with modern toolchains,  reusable and standardized APIs as well as improved operational efficiency.

Transition Path 2: Consolidation

Many of our customers are looking to reduce the number of integration platforms (platform sprawl) and address operational overheads by centralizing an enterprise-wide integration strategy.

This transition path will help organizations seeking simplification, fewer platforms to secure and monitor, and easier governance.

Transition Path 3: Lift-and-Shift

Moving existing interfaces to SAP Integration Suite with minimal code change. Often used as an initial wave to establish alignment with the cloud transition journey and to adopt the latest and strategic integration platform offered by SAP.

While this is the fastest path to moving away from legacy platform, here customers will miss the opportunity to adopt cloud-native patterns or bring in design efficiencies. This path may lead rework to realize full benefits, but is definitely useful as a pragmatic first step in a phased modernization strategy.

Phased approaches

We have also observed customers blend various approaches: modernize high-value or frequently changing interfaces, consolidate integrations that have been created across multiple platforms to a single enterprise-wide solution, and lift-and-shift stable integrations that require less change. This mix of approaches has been found to help deliver near-term simplification while paving the way for long-term modernization.

---------------------------------------

To ease the transition paths chosen by customers and to make the migration/modernization approaches predictable and repeatable we’ve focused our investments on product, tooling, people enablement, and eco-system involvement.

This blog aims to consolidate the different blogs and sources of information available in this context to capture the improvements done in each of these areas in the last few months.

Product Enhancements

In the last few releases, we have consciously also invested in supporting features that will mainly support our SAP Process Orchestration customers when migrating to SAP Integration Suite like – import of Service Interfaces, Data Type, Message Type, Functional Libraries, ABAP proxy generation, guaranteed Exactly Once in Order support via JMS, AEM(design guideline), Pipeline concept, and many more

I highly recommend reading the "What’s new with SAP Integration Suite" quarterly blogs published by my colleagues which very well capture these enhancements - https://community.sap.com/t5/tag/WhatsNewInSAPIntegrationSuite/tg-p/board-id/technology-blog-sap

In addition, would like to point you to our strong roadmap - https://roadmaps.sap.com/board?PRODUCT=73554900100800003241 - that shows our intent to meet the customer expectations and needs mainly in the context of the modernization and consolidation related paths.

This ongoing dialogue keeps everyone aligned and evolving together.
